Award.AwardTitle: Data on the mind: Center for Data-Intensive Psychological Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Psychological research has traditionally been conducted using laboratory experiments, bringing a small number of people into a research laboratory and asking them to complete a task. But the existence--and increasing availability--of online datasets on human behavior and new technologies for data collection suggests a different approach might be possible: mining large databases for clues about how people reason, learn, and interact. Dr. Griffiths, Dr. Gopnik, and Dr. Keltner will establish a research center at the University of California, Berkeley to explore the potential of this data-intensive approach to psychological science. The research center will work with a network of researchers across the country and companies developing technologies for collection of behavioral data to establish pilot projects in cognitive psychology, developmental psychology, and social psychology. These pilot projects will include examining what online databases reveal about human reasoning, how mobile devices can be used to study how children learn, and whether interactions on social networking websites can answer questions about human emotion.

"Big data" research is currently dominated by computer scientists and statisticians, but the questions that are often the focus of this research "understanding human behavior" have traditionally been the domain of psychologists. The new research center for data-intensive psychological science will bring these groups together by establishing collaborations between researchers and developing a curriculum for training students to work at the intersection of these disciplines. The results will be potentially transformative for psychological research, taking it out of the laboratory and into the world. By asking questions that are motivated by decades of psychological theory, data-intensive psychological research will provide new insights into analyzing large behavioral datasets that are potentially relevant to any research project or commercial enterprise that relies upon this kind of data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Psychological research has the potential to be transformed by the availability of large online databases that give a richer and more detailed picture of human behavior than ever before. This project aimed to prepare researchers for this transformation, creating a website that provides access to a large array of behavioral data sets, suporting pilot projects that illustrate the potential of data intensive psychological research, providing training to young researchers, and bringing together academics and researchers in industry to discuss how to apply these methods.

The project achieved all of these goals. One of the primary outcomes of the project is the website dataonthemind.org,  which provides a range of resources to the research community. First, it aggregates behavioral databases of many kinds, labeling each with the aspects of human cognition that are involved. This  makes it easier for researchers to see how these kinds of data could be used to answer their research questions. Second, it hosts links to tutorials and videos of training sessions that researchers can use to learn these new methods. Finally, it highlights research projects that have used these methods and the researchers who carried them out.

 The material on the website was developed as a result of two workshops. The first workshop brought together researchers in academia and industry and identified the kinds of resources that exist and the gaps in training that need to be addressed. The second workshop focused on younger researchers, providing a series of tutorials and opportunities for researchers with an interest in data intensive approaches to human behavior to interact with one another. The tutorials were captured on video, streamed to the Internet, and edited to appear in final form on the website.

 This grant also supported a number of pilot projects that explored how data intensive methods could be used in cognitive psychology, psycholinguistics, and developmental psychology, helping us to better understand how people think, interact, and develop over time.
